events.event_description: U.S. electricity demand reached its summer peak of 745 GWh at 6:00 p.m. EDT, nearly matching peaks from previous years.
events.citation: Last summer, U.S. electricity demand in the Lower 48 states was greatest at 6:00 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time on July 15, 2024, when it reached about 745 gigawatthours (GWh)

events.event_description: Baltimore and Washington DC experienced extreme temperatures above 100°F for several consecutive days.
events.citation: both Baltimore, Maryland, and Washington, DC, experienced high temperatures of 100°F or above from July 14 to 17

events.event_description: Hurricane Debby moved up the East Coast causing rain and power outages that impacted electricity demand.
events.citation: demand was curbed by the rain and power outages due to Hurricane Debby, which moved up the East Coast from August 4 to 10

events.event_description: Texas electricity demand peaked at 86 GWh, matching its previous all-time record.
events.citation: In Texas, hourly electricity demand peaked on August 20, reaching about 86 GWh, which is virtually the same as the previous all-time daily peak of 85 GWh reached in August 2023

events.event_description: Hurricane Beryl hit Texas coastline, causing electricity demand to fall by about a third to 55 GWh.
events.citation: demand fell by about a third to 55 GWh by July 8, when Hurricane Beryl reached the Texas coastline

events.event_description: Western Interconnection set a new record peak demand of 168 GWh including Canadian provinces.
events.citation: With the two Canadian provinces, electricity demand reached about 168 GWh on July 10, setting a new record

events.event_description: California's power system peaked at 45 GWh, below its previous record of 52 GWh from 2022.
events.citation: CAISO said electricity demand on its system, which also covers part of Nevada, peaked on July 24 at about 45 GWh, which was less than the record of 52 GWh that occurred on September 6, 2022
